title: 107_hr3176
content: The Act titled "Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act" establishes protocols for national responses to public health emergencies involving dangerous biological agents or chemicals. The Hazardous Agent Emergency Uniform Response Act mandates the development of protocols by the Secretary of Health and Human Services for responding to public health emergencies caused by dangerous biological agents or chemicals, including intentional releases. The Secretary must also consult with states, including public health officers and attorneys general. The Secretary must consult with states, including public health officers and attorneys general, regarding hazardous agents, defined as dangerous biological agents and chemicals. The Secretary, in consultation with the Chemical Safety and states, must list dangerous chemicals within 45 days of the Act's enactment. After the enactment of this Act, the Secretary, in consultation with the Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board, will develop a list of chemicals known or anticipated to cause serious adverse effects on human health. This list will include substances listed under section 112(r)(3) of the Clean Air Act. The Secretary will develop a list of chemicals known to cause serious adverse effects on human health, including substances listed under section 112(r)(3) of the Clean Air Act. Protocols specific to each hazardous agent will be created, unless the agent has no unique characteristics. The Secretary will establish priorities for hazardous agents within 45 days of the Act's enactment and develop protocols promptly after. The Secretary will develop protocols for hazardous agents promptly after establishing priorities, seeking completion within 45 days for each protocol under subsection (a). The provisions of the protocol will ensure uniform application. The protocol developed by the Secretary for hazardous agents must ensure uniform application in public health emergencies, coordinate with emergency response personnel, and provide timely medical information to individuals present at the site of the emergency. The Secretary shall periodically review provisions for responding to public health emergencies involving hazardous agents, including testing, treating affected individuals, decontaminating sites, and differentiating between accidental and intentional releases. The Secretary periodically reviews protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving hazardous agents and may revise them as needed. Development exemptions may apply if existing protocols meet requirements. The Secretary periodically reviews and revises protocols for responding to public health emergencies involving hazardous agents. Development exemptions may be granted for certain hazardous agents. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2002 through 2006 to carry out this section.
